title: Domain 2.5: Given a scenario, install and configure basic wired/wireless small office/home office SOHO networks.
content:
🌐 2.5 – Internet Protocol (IP) Addressing

📦 IPv4 (Internet Protocol Version 4)

32-bit address (example: 192.168.1.1)
Written as four octets, separated by dots
Total: ~4.3 billion unique addresses

🔐 Private IP Addresses (Not Routable on Internet)

  • Class A: 10.0.0.0 – 10.255.255.255
  • Class B: 172.16.0.0 – 172.31.255.255
  • Class C: 192.168.0.0 – 192.168.255.255

🧠 Tip: Used in homes and businesses behind routers with NAT.

🌍 Public IP Addresses

Routable on the internet
Assigned by ISPs
Must be unique

🧠 Tip: If a device has a public IP, it’s exposed to the internet unless protected by a firewall.

🆕 IPv6 (Internet Protocol Version 6)

128-bit address (example: 2001:0db8:85a3::8a2e:0370:7334)
Designed to replace IPv4 due to exhaustion
Has enormous address space
Includes built-in security and auto-config features

🧠 Tip: Often used in modern enterprise and ISP infrastructure.

🤖 APIPA (Automatic Private IP Addressing)

Range: 169.254.0.1 – 169.254.255.254
Used when a device can’t reach a DHCP server
Device assigns itself a private address for local comms only

🧠 Tip: Can’t reach the internet with an APIPA address!

📍 Static IP Addressing

Manually assigned IP address
Used for:

  • Servers
  • Printers
  • Routers
  • Devices needing consistent address

🧠 Tip: Ensure no IP conflicts when assigning static addresses.

🔄 Dynamic IP Addressing

Assigned by a DHCP server
Automatically configured (IP, subnet, gateway, DNS)

🧠 Tip: Common for desktops, laptops, mobile devices.

🌐 Gateway

Usually the router’s IP address
Acts as the exit point from the LAN to the Internet
All outbound traffic flows through the gateway

🧠 Tip: If a device can reach local devices but not the internet → check gateway settings.
